title: Ruhi Sarıalp
text:
Ruhi Sarıalp (December 15, 1924 – March 3, 2001) was a <a href="Turkish%20people">Turkish</a> <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> athlete, who competed mainly in the <a href="triple%20jump">triple jump</a>. He was born in <a href="Manisa">Manisa</a>.
Background.
He competed for Turkey in the <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a> held in <a href="London">London</a>, <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> in the triple jump, where he won the bronze medal with a mark of 15.02 m.
He started <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a> during his education at the military high school in <a href="Konya">Konya</a>. In 1945, he broke the Turkish record in triple jump. After his bronze medal jump at the Olympics, he won another bronze medal at the 1950 <a href="European%20Athletics%20Championships">European Athletics Championships</a> in <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a>, <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>. He became so the first ever track and field athlete from Turkey to win a medal at the Olympics and the European Championships. Ruhi Sarıalp became champion at the World Military Athletics Championships held 1951 in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a> by breaking the World record. He repeated his first place in the same championships of 1952.
After leaving the active sports, Ruhi Sarıalp served as a lecturer for <a href="physical%20education">physical education</a> in the School of Maritime at <a href="Istanbul%20Technical%20University">Istanbul Technical University</a> (İTÜ). The indoor sports hall of İTÜ, located in the <a href="Tuzla%20%28district%29">Tuzla</a> district of <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, is named after him. He was a member of the supreme council of the <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20SK">Fenerbahçe SK</a> athletic branch <a href="Fenerbah%C3%A7e%20Athletics">Fenerbahçe Athletics</a>.
He died on March 3, 2001 in <a href="Izmir">Izmir</a> due to <a href="agonal%20respiration">agonal respiration</a>, and was buried in the <a href="Edirnekap%C4%B1%20Martyr%27s%20Cemetery">Edirnekapı Martyr's Cemetery</a> in Istanbul. He was married with Ayşe Cebesoy, a <a href="cousin">niece</a> of the renowned Turkish statesman <a href="Ali%20Fuat%20Cebesoy">Ali Fuat Cebesoy</a>.
